docs.text:
Fellow transforms Claude Code from a generic AI assistant into an expert on YOUR specific codebase.

It extracts semantic knowledge from your code - entities, workflows, patterns, and constraints - then automatically enriches every coding request with relevant context. The result: architecturally-correct AI suggestions in seconds, not minutes.

docs.title: Installing Claude Code CLI
docs.text: This guide explains how to install the Claude Code CLI, which is required for installing and managing plugins like Fellow.

docs.title: Why Install the CLI?
docs.text:
CLI Required for Plugins

Even if you only plan to use VS Code, you need the Claude Code CLI to install plugins. The VS Code extension does not include plugin installation capabilities.

What you need the CLI for: - ✅ Installing plugins (like Fellow) - ✅ Managing plugin configuration - ✅ Configuring MCP servers - ✅ Using Claude Code in terminal

What you don't need the CLI for: - Using the VS Code extension for basic conversations - Code generation and editing in VS Code - @-mentioning files in VS Code

  3. Run the .pkg installer

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Fellow - Architectural Guardrails for Claude Code

This guide explains how to install Fellow, a Claude Code plugin that automatically enriches every request to prevent architectural drift and enforce codebase consistency.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before installing Fellow, ensure you have:

  • Claude Code CLI - Required for plugin installation (even for VS Code users!)
  • Python 3.8 or higher (for knowledge extraction agents)
  • Git (optional, for cloning from source)

CLI Required for Plugin Installation

The VS Code extension does NOT include the claude CLI command. You must install the Claude Code CLI separately to install plugins, even if you only plan to use VS Code.

Install Claude Code CLI →

VS Code Users

Fellow works seamlessly with the Claude Code VS Code extension! But you still need the CLI to install Fellow first. After CLI installation via marketplace commands, Fellow automatically works in both CLI and VS Code.

docs.title: Quick Installation
docs.text:
The fastest way to install Fellow:

# Install Fellow from the marketplace
/plugin install fellow

That's it! Fellow will be automatically downloaded, verified, and enabled.

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
Check that Fellow is installed and working:

# List installed plugins
/plugin list

You should see: 

✓ fellow@user (v2.1.0) - Semantic knowledge extraction and context enrichment

Verify Fellow commands are available:

# These commands should now work:
/build-kb --help
/toggle-hooks status

docs.title: Installation Methods
docs.text: Choose the installation method that fits your needs:

docs.title: Method 1: Local Clone (Current - Required Until Published)
docs.text:
Required right now since Fellow is not yet in the official marketplace.

Best for: Everyone (current only option)

# Step 1: Clone Fellow repository
git clone https://github.com/jingnanzhou/fellow.git
cd fellow

# Step 2: Add as local marketplace
claude plugin marketplace add ./

# Step 3: Install from local marketplace
claude plugin marketplace install fellow@local_marketplace

# Step 4: Verify
claude plugin list

What this does: - Registers the directory as a local marketplace - Reads plugin.json from the marketplace - Installs Fellow from local marketplace - Enables Fellow automatically

Pros: - ✅ Works immediately (no official marketplace needed) - ✅ Full control over plugin code - ✅ Can update by pulling latest changes - ✅ Can modify and customize

docs.title: Method 2: From Marketplace (After Publishing - Future)
docs.text:
Will work after Fellow is published to the official Claude Code marketplace.

# Simple one-command installation (future)
claude plugin install fellow

# Verify
claude plugin list

When available: - After Anthropic reviews and approves Fellow - Expected timeline: 2-4 weeks after submission

Pros (when available): - ✅ Simple one-command installation - ✅ Automatic updates available - ✅ Verified and tested releases - ✅ Security-checked by Claude Code

docs.title: Method 3: Removing the Plugin
docs.text:
To uninstall Fellow:

# Step 1: Uninstall the plugin
claude plugin uninstall fellow@local_marketplace

# Step 2: Remove the marketplace
claude plugin marketplace remove local_marketplace

What this does: - Removes Fellow plugin from Claude Code - Removes the local marketplace reference

docs.title: Where is Fellow Installed?
docs.text:
Claude Code copies Fellow to a secure cache directory for verification:

Operating System Plugin Cache Location macOS ~/.claude/cache/plugins/fellow/ Linux ~/.claude/cache/plugins/fellow/ Windows %APPDATA%\ClaudeCode\cache\plugins\fellow\

Why a cache directory?

Claude Code copies plugins to a cache for security verification. This ensures plugins can't modify themselves after installation.

docs.title: Default Settings
docs.text:
Fellow comes pre-configured with sensible defaults:

  • ✅ Automatic enrichment: Enabled
  • ✅ Hook detection confidence: 0.7 threshold
  • ✅ Silent mode: Disabled (shows enriched context)
  • ✅ Logging: Disabled (enable with FELLOW_LOGGING=1)

docs.title: Customizing Fellow
docs.text:
To customize Fellow's behavior, edit the hook configuration:

Location: Find it in Claude Code's plugin cache at: - macOS/Linux: ~/.claude/cache/plugins/fellow/.claude-plugin/hooks.json - Windows: %APPDATA%\ClaudeCode\cache\plugins\fellow\.claude-plugin\hooks.json

Configuration options:

{
  "hooks": [{
    "name": "fellow-context-enrichment",
    "enabled": true,
    "config": {
      "min_confidence": 0.7,
      "silent_mode": false,
      "logging_enabled": false,
      "keywords": ["add", "create", "implement", ...]
    }
  }]
}

Settings explained:

Setting Values Description enabled true/false Enable/disable automatic enrichment min_confidence 0.5 - 1.0 Detection threshold (higher = stricter) silent_mode true/false Hide enriched context from display logging_enabled true/false Log all enrichment events keywords Array of strings Keywords for coding request detection

Recommended settings by use case:

Learning FellowProduction UseConservativeAggressive 

{
  "min_confidence": 0.7,
  "silent_mode": false,
  "logging_enabled": true
}
Best for: Understanding how Fellow works

{
  "min_confidence": 0.7,
  "silent_mode": false,
  "logging_enabled": false
}
Best for: Daily development work

{
  "min_confidence": 0.9,
  "silent_mode": false,
  "logging_enabled": false
}
Best for: Only enrich very obvious coding requests

{
  "min_confidence": 0.5,
  "silent_mode": false,
  "logging_enabled": true
}
Best for: Maximum enrichment, log to verify accuracy

docs.title: Enable Logging
docs.text:
To see what context Fellow is adding:

Method 1: Environment variable 

export FELLOW_LOGGING=1

Method 2: Edit hooks.json 

{
  "config": {
    "logging_enabled": true
  }
}

Logs will be created in your project at: 

.fellow-data/logs/
├── enrichment_2026-01-05.jsonl    # Machine-readable
└── enrichment_2026-01-05.log      # Human-readable

  2. Extract entities - Finds classes, functions, services, models
  3. Map workflows - Traces execution flows and integration patterns
  4. Identify patterns - Discovers your architectural patterns
  5. Capture constraints - Extracts security, performance, and validation rules

docs.title: What Fellow Does Automatically
docs.text:
1. Detects coding intent - Recognizes this as a code modification request
  2. Loads knowledge base - Retrieves relevant knowledge from .fellow-data/semantic/
  3. Finds relevant entities - Identifies UserModel, ValidationService, etc.
  4. Retrieves workflows - Finds your existing registration workflow
  5. Applies constraints - Loads security and validation rules
  6. Enriches context - Prepends all this information to your request

docs.title: What You'll See
docs.text:
📋 **Context from Knowledge Base**

**Relevant Entities:**
- **UserModel** (class): User entity with validation rules
  Location: `src/models/user.py`
- **ValidationService** (class): Centralized validation logic
  Location: `src/services/validation.py`
- **RegistrationHandler** (class): Handles user registration workflow
  Location: `src/handlers/registration.py`

**Relevant Workflows:**
- **User Registration Flow**: Complete user registration with validation
  Entry: `src/handlers/registration.py`

- [Security] Passwords must be hashed with bcrypt
- [Validation] Email format must match RFC 5322
- [Architecture] Use ValidationService for all input validation
- [Data] User emails must be unique (database constraint)

**Architecture Style:** Service-Oriented Architecture

  • Full extraction: 2-5 minutes
  • Incremental update: 10-20 seconds

Fellow detects changed files and only re-extracts those files.

- Modified: src/services/validation.py

- Conceptual: No architectural changes

Time: 12 seconds (15x faster than full extraction)

docs.title: Scenario 1: Large Codebase
docs.text:
First extraction takes longer for large codebases

  • Small project (< 10K LOC): 1-2 minutes
  • Medium project (10-50K LOC): 2-3 minutes
  • Large project (50-200K LOC): 3-5 minutes
  • Very large (200K+ LOC): 5-10 minutes

This is a one-time cost. Subsequent incremental updates take 10-20 seconds.

docs.title: Scenario 2: "Knowledge base not found"
docs.text:
If you try enriched coding without building the KB first:

❌ Knowledge base not found
Please run /build-kb first to extract semantic knowledge

Solution: Run /build-kb in your project directory.

docs.title: Scenario 3: Non-Coding Request
docs.text:
If you ask a question (not a coding request):

"What is the architecture of this project?"

Fellow recognizes this isn't a coding request and passes through unchanged. No enrichment is added.

docs.title: Scenario 4: Multiple Projects
docs.text:

cd /path/to/project-a
/build-kb
# Creates .fellow-data/ in project-a

# Project B
cd /path/to/project-b
/build-kb
# Creates .fellow-data/ in project-b

# Coding in Project A
cd /path/to/project-a
"Add feature X"  # Uses project-a knowledge base

# Coding in Project B
cd /path/to/project-b
"Add feature Y"  # Uses project-b knowledge base

docs.title: Issue: "Hook not intercepting my requests"
docs.text:
Check 1: Verify hooks are enabled

/toggle-hooks status

Check 2: Is your request a coding request?

Fellow detects coding keywords like: - add, create, implement, build - update, modify, refactor - fix, debug, resolve - delete, remove

Questions like "What is..." or "Show me..." are not detected as coding requests.

Solution: Use /fellow command explicitly:

/fellow Add feature X

docs.title: Issue: "Knowledge base seems outdated"
docs.text:
Solution: Run incremental update:

/build-kb --update

Or force full rebuild:

/build-kb --full

docs.text:
This is normal for first extraction. Grab a coffee ☕

Tips to speed up: - Exclude unnecessary directories (node_modules, vendor, etc.) - we detect these automatically - Use incremental updates for subsequent extractions

docs.title: What is Fellow?
docs.text: Fellow is a semantic knowledge extraction and context enrichment plugin for Claude Code. It extracts patterns, workflows, and constraints from your codebase and automatically enriches AI coding requests with relevant context.

docs.title: How is Fellow different from Copilot?
docs.text: Copilot suggests code based on general patterns. Fellow makes AI understand YOUR specific codebase - YOUR patterns, YOUR constraints, YOUR architecture.

docs.title: Is Fellow free?
docs.text: Yes! Fellow is open source under Apache 2.0 license. Free for individuals, teams, and commercial use.

docs.title: How do I install Fellow?
docs.text: Clone the repository - Claude Code will auto-detect it. See Installation Guide.

docs.title: How long does the first extraction take?
docs.text: 2-5 minutes for most projects. Large codebases (200K+ LOC) may take 5-10 minutes.

docs.title: Can I use Fellow on multiple projects?
docs.text: Yes! Each project gets its own knowledge base in .fellow-data/semantic/.

docs.title: Do I need to use a special command every time?
docs.text: No! By default, hooks are enabled. Fellow automatically enriches coding requests. No manual commands needed.

docs.title: What if I want to disable automatic enrichment?
docs.text: Run /toggle-hooks off. You can still use /fellow for manual enrichment.

docs.title: How do I keep the knowledge base current?
docs.text: Run /build-kb --update after code changes. Takes 10-20 seconds (incremental update).

docs.title: Fellow isn't enriching my requests
docs.text: Check if hooks are enabled: /toggle-hooks status. Make sure your request uses coding keywords (add, create, fix, etc.).

docs.title: Knowledge base seems outdated
docs.text: Run /build-kb --update to incrementally update based on code changes.

docs.title: Can I see what context is being added?
docs.text: Enable logging: export FELLOW_LOGGING=1. Check .fellow-data/logs/.

docs.title: Where is my code sent?
docs.text: Nowhere! Fellow runs entirely locally. Your code never leaves your machine.

docs.title: What data does Fellow collect?
docs.text: None. Fellow is open source - audit the code yourself.

docs.title: Can I use Fellow on private/proprietary codebases?
docs.text: Yes! Everything runs locally. No data transmission.

docs.title: Can I customize the extraction?
docs.text: Yes! You can modify extraction agents in agents/ directory. See Contributing Guide.

docs.title: Does Fellow support my programming language?
docs.text: Fellow is language-agnostic. It analyzes code structure regardless of language.

docs.title: Can I integrate with CI/CD?
docs.text: Yes! Run /build-kb --update in your CI pipeline. See CI/CD Integration.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Fellow supports incremental updates to the knowledge base, allowing you to efficiently update only the changed parts of your codebase instead of re-analyzing everything.

docs.title: Initial Build (Full Extraction)
docs.text:
/build-kb

Creates: - .fellow-data/semantic/factual_knowledge.json - .fellow-data/semantic/procedural_knowledge.json - .fellow-data/semantic/conceptual_knowledge.json - .fellow-data/semantic/SEMANTIC_KNOWLEDGE_SUMMARY.md - .fellow-data/semantic/extraction_metadata.json (tracks extraction state)

docs.title: Incremental Update
docs.text:
/build-kb --update
# or simply
/build-kb

If knowledge base already exists, automatically performs incremental update: 1. Detects changed files (via git or file modification time) 2. Re-extracts knowledge only for changed files 3. Merges new knowledge with existing knowledge base 4. Updates metadata and summary

docs.title: Force Full Rebuild
docs.text:
/build-kb --full

Forces complete re-extraction even if knowledge base exists.

docs.title: 1. Git-Based (Preferred)
docs.text:
If project is a git repository:

# Detect changed files since last extraction
git diff --name-only <last_commit_hash> HEAD

# Detect uncommitted changes
git diff --name-only
git ls-files --others --exclude-standard

Advantages: - Precise change tracking - Handles renames and moves - Integrates with version control - Tracks deletions

Advantages: - Works without git - Simple and reliable - Fast detection

docs.title: 3. File Hash Comparison
docs.text:
Calculate SHA-256 hash and compare with stored hashes:

import hashlib

def file_hash(filepath):
    sha256 = hashlib.sha256()
    with open(filepath, 'rb') as f:
        for chunk in iter(lambda: f.read(4096), b""):
            sha256.update(chunk)
    return sha256.hexdigest()

Advantages: - Most accurate - Detects content changes even if mtime unchanged - Cross-platform

docs.title: Phase 1: Change Detection
docs.text:
1. Load metadata: Read extraction_metadata.json
  2. Detect changes:
  3. Use git if available: git diff --name-only <commit>
  4. Fall back to file modification time
  5. Calculate hashes if needed
  6. Categorize changes:
  7. Modified files: Re-extract knowledge
  8. New files: Extract knowledge
  9. Deleted files: Remove from knowledge base
  10. Renamed files: Update references

docs.title: Phase 2: Targeted Extraction
docs.text:
For Modified/New Files:

  1. Factual Knowledge:
  2. Extract entities from changed files
  3. Update relationships involving these entities
  4. Remove old entities from these files

  5. Add new entities

  6. Procedural Knowledge:

  7. Re-analyze workflows starting from changed files
  8. Update affected workflows

  9. Remove workflows that no longer exist

  10. Conceptual Knowledge:

  11. Typically requires full re-analysis (architecture overview)
  12. Or: Only update if architectural changes detected

docs.title: Phase 3: Knowledge Base Merge
docs.text:
Merge Strategy:

# Pseudo-code for merge logic

def merge_factual_knowledge(existing, new_extraction, changed_files):
    # Remove entities from changed files
    existing_entities = [
        e for e in existing["entities"]
        if e["grounding"]["file"] not in changed_files
    ]

    # Add newly extracted entities
    updated_entities = existing_entities + new_extraction["entities"]

    # Update relationships
    updated_relationships = update_relationships(
        existing["entity_relationships"],
        new_extraction["entity_relationships"],
        changed_files
    )

    return {
        "metadata": update_metadata(existing["metadata"]),
        "entities": updated_entities,
        "entity_relationships": updated_relationships,
        "summary": recalculate_summary(updated_entities)
    }

Conflict Resolution: - Entity name conflicts: Use file path + line number as unique identifier - Relationship updates: Remove old, add new - Metadata merging: Keep historical info, update current stats

docs.title: When Incremental Updates May Not Suffice
docs.text:
1. Major Refactoring: Renaming entities, moving files

  2. Solution: Force full rebuild with --full

  3. Relationship Changes: When unchanged files now depend on changed files

  4. Solution: Enhanced relationship tracking (future improvement)

  5. Architectural Changes: Layer restructuring, pattern changes

  6. Solution: Conceptual knowledge always does targeted re-analysis

  7. Git History Lost: After rebasing, squashing commits

  8. Solution: Fall back to hash-based detection
